title: How to Dry Hop Beer

methods.name: Dry Hopping Beer During Secondary Fermentation

steps.headline: Siphon your freshly-fermented beer into a secondary fermenter.
steps.description: Set your secondary fermenter on the ground or a low shelf 2–3 feet (0.61–0.91 m) below your primary fermenter. Insert one end of an auto-siphon into the primary fermenter so that it sits just over the bottom of the container, then place the opposite end into the secondary fermenter and pump the siphon a couple times to get the flow started. After a few seconds, gravity will cause the beer to drain out of the higher fermenter and into the lower one. Squeeze the hose clamp on the auto-siphon to control how fast the liquid flows through the hose. Be sure to run some sanitizer solution through your auto-siphon before and after the transition to avoid contaminating or throwing off the flavor of the beer.

steps.headline: Add your preferred quantity of hops.
steps.description: Before you seal your secondary fermenter, dump in your preferred quantity of hops. The exact variety and amount of hops you use will depend on the particular style of beer you’re brewing, so make sure you’ve done your homework. A standard measurement is about 1–2 ounces (28–57 g) for every 5 gallons (19 L) of beer. You can find a wealth of homebrew recipes using both single hop varieties and blends online through resources like Brewer's Friend and the American Homebrewer's Association. If you’re using whole leaf hops, you can simply drop them into the fermenter. If you’re working with pellet hops, it’s recommended that you place them inside a hop bag or strainer to make straining and cleanup easier later on.

steps.headline: Allow the hops to steep for 5-7 days.
steps.description: A week’s worth of steeping will give the hops a chance to impart their full flavor to the beer. During this time, avoid opening the secondary fermenter for any reason. It needs to stay sealed in order for the oxygen and carbon dioxide in the beer to stay balanced. Avoid leaving the hops to steep for longer than 2-3 weeks. If they sit for too long, they can begin releasing unpleasant grassy notes that can spoil the beer’s more nuanced flavors.

steps.headline: Strain the hops and enjoy.
steps.description: Once you’ve let your beer steep for as long as you like, open the secondary fermenter and remove the spent hops. If you used a hop bag or strainer, simply pull it out and discard the contents. You can use a mesh basket to collect the remnants of whole leaf hops. As you take your first sip of the beer, pay special attention to the intensity of the hoppy flavor. If it’s too faint, you’ll know to add more next time, whereas if it’s too strong you can cut back a little to get the taste just right. Try to get your beer into a keg or bottles shortly after opening your secondary fermenter to preserve its freshness and flavor.

steps.headline: Transfer your finished batch of beer to a keg.
steps.description: Use an auto-siphon to drain the beer out of your secondary fermenter and into an awaiting container. For this method, you’ll wait until after your beer has completed the fermentation process before introducing the hops. You can typically find locking, stainless steel kegs in various sizes for less than $100 at most homebrew supply shops. Racking your beer into a keg rather than individual bottles will keep it tasting fresher longer, reduce the risk of contamination, and allow you to enjoy only as much as you want at one time.

steps.headline: Place the desired amount of hops directly in the keg.
steps.description: Drop whole leaf hops into the opening of the keg before sealing it off. Pour pellet hops into a hop bag to help keep them contained and simplify the cleanup process. If you’re not sure how much to use, 1–2 ounces (28–57 g) for every 5 gallons (19 L) is a safe amount for most pale ales. If you add loose pellet hops to the keg, there’s a chance that small particles may clog the uptake lines, or even find their way into your glass. Putting a handful of marbles at the bottom of the hop bag will help it sink deeper into the keg, improving its exposure.

steps.headline: Use up the keg within 3-7 days.
steps.description: Once you've added your hops, you can simply savor your beer straight from the keg. Keep in mind that hops tend to turn sour faster in a keg than they do in a fermenter. For this reason, it’s best to enjoy your homebrew before it has a chance to take on the plant-like flavors of the decomposing hops. There's no need to worry about straining the hops, as long as you use a whole leaf variety or hop bag. When you pour a glass from the keg, the beer will pass through the layer of hops floating on the surface, ensuring that every sip is full of complex flavor. If you need to get rid of a large quantity of beer in a hurry, invite a few friends over for a private tasting. It’s guaranteed to disappear fast!

methods.name: Testing Small Batches in a French Press

steps.headline: Fill a French press with freshly-brewed beer.
steps.description: Funnel 25–30 fluid ounces (0.74–0.89 L) of beer into the chamber of the French press using an auto-siphon. You don’t need to fill the French press all the way to the brim—just pour in enough to infuse with a proportionate quantity of hops and let you and your associates have a few good sips. You might use even less beer, depending on how many test runs you plan on performing. It’s important that the French press is clean and sterile before you begin running in the beer, especially if you’ve used it to brew coffee previously.

steps.headline: Add a handful of hops.
steps.description: Sprinkle a small quantity of full leaf or pellet hops onto the surface of the beer. Since dry hopping in a French press is more of a fun experiment than an exact science, it’s not necessary to be too precise. Once you’ve loaded up your hops, put the lid on the French press. This can be a good opportunity to see how a single type of hops influences the character of a batch of beer. You could also bring together multiple varieties to explore interesting new combinations. Don’t worry about using a hop bag this go-around. The cool thing about using a French press is that it comes with its own built-in strainer!

steps.headline: Let the hops steep for 3-10 minutes at room temperature.
steps.description: Unlike larger batches, your test batch won’t need to infuse for very long. Within just a few minutes, the hops will have begun giving off their signature bright, tangy, pleasantly-bitter bite. If you favor an especially hoppy brew, leave the hops to steep for up to 20 minutes. Any longer than that and their flavor may become overpowering.

steps.headline: Strain and sample the beer.
steps.description: When you’re ready to try out your brew, press down on the plunger on the lid of the French press slowly until it rests against the bottom of the chamber. The fine mesh of the filter screen should catch all the little bits floating around, even if you’re using pellet hops. Pour some beer into a small glass and see how it tastes! Don’t be surprised if your beer tastes slightly flat. The action of the plunger may disrupt a little bit of the carbon dioxide in the suspension. You should still be able to get a good idea of how a given infusion will taste in a large batch. One of the major benefits of dry hopping in a French press is that if you don’t like the way one batch comes out, you can whip up another batch with a different hop-to-beer ratio in minutes.
